name: Energy Calculations and Costs
what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is measured in kilowatt-hours, how to calculate energy consumption from power ratings, and how to determine the cost of running electrical appliances.
why: Understanding energy calculations helps you make informed decisions about appliance usage, compare running costs, and interpret electricity bills. These skills support both financial and environmental awareness.

items.title: I can explain why the kilowatt-hour is used as a domestic unit of energy
items.what: The kilowatt-hour (kWh) is more convenient than joules for domestic use because it directly relates to appliance power ratings (in kW) and usage time (in hours).
items.why: Using kWh makes it easy to calculate energy consumption from information readily available on appliance labels and usage patterns.
items.example: A 2kW heater used for 3 hours consumes 2 Ã— 3 = 6 kWh. In joules, this would be 6 Ã— 3,600,000 = 21,600,000 J, which is harder to work with.

items.title: I can convert between kilowatt-hours and joules
items.what: One kilowatt-hour equals 3.6 megajoules (MJ). This comes from 1 kW = 1000 J/s and 1 hour = 3600 s, so 1 kWh = 1000 Ã— 3600 = 3,600,000 J.
items.why: Converting between units allows you to connect domestic energy usage to physics calculations using SI units.
items.example: A household using 15 kWh per day consumes 15 Ã— 3.6 = 54 MJ of electrical energy daily.

items.title: I can calculate the energy consumed by an appliance using E = Pt
items.what: Energy consumed equals power multiplied by time: E = P Ã— t. With power in kilowatts and time in hours, the result is in kilowatt-hours.
items.why: This formula allows you to calculate energy usage for any appliance if you know its power rating and how long it operates.
items.example: A 3kW kettle used for 5 minutes (5/60 = 0.083 hours) consumes E = 3 Ã— 0.083 = 0.25 kWh.

items.title: I can calculate the current drawn by an appliance using P = VI
items.what: Current can be found by rearranging P = VI to I = P/V. For mains appliances, V = 230V.
items.why: Knowing the current drawn helps determine whether appliances can safely share a circuit with a given fuse or circuit breaker rating.
items.example: A 2300W heater draws I = 2300/230 = 10A from the mains supply.

items.title: I can calculate the cost of running an appliance
items.what: Cost equals energy consumed (in kWh) multiplied by the price per kWh. Cost = P (kW) Ã— t (hours) Ã— price ($/kWh).
items.why: Calculating running costs helps you make economical choices about appliance usage and understand electricity bills.
items.example: A 2kW heater used for 4 hours at $0.30/kWh costs: 2 Ã— 4 Ã— 0.30 = $2.40.

items.title: I can interpret appliance energy ratings and compare efficiency
items.what: Energy rating labels show power consumption and star ratings. More stars indicate greater efficiency (lower running cost for the same output).
items.why: Understanding ratings helps you choose appliances that minimise energy costs and environmental impact over their lifetime.
items.example: A 5-star rated 200L refrigerator might use 200 kWh per year, while a 2-star model of the same size might use 400 kWh per year.

items.title: I can calculate standby power consumption over time
items.what: Standby power, though small (typically 0.5-5W), accumulates over hours and days. Annual standby consumption can be significant.
items.why: Standby power accounts for about 3% of household electricity use, making it worth considering when reducing energy costs.
items.example: A TV using 2W on standby for 22 hours/day: E = 0.002 Ã— 22 Ã— 365 = 16 kWh/year, costing about $4.80 annually at $0.30/kWh.
